newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's Matav confirms plans major flotation.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's Matav confirms plans major flotation.

text.p: Hungarian telecommunications company Matav confirmed on Friday it is planning a major flotation but an official declined to give the exact amount or say when the offering would be made.
"We have a very interesting plan and it will be a major IPO in the region," Geza Laszlo, chief economist of Investel, the financial subsidiary of MATAV, told Reuters.
Laszlo declined to confirm a report in the Financial Times that the amount of the IPO would be $500 million, saying "we haven't decided yet the percent to be sold".
The newspaper said the flotation was expected within the next 18 months, but Laszlo said the date had yet to be set.
"We are going to be looking for the best timing," he said.
He said the flotation would affect holdings of the biggest investors in Matav, Deutsche Telekom and Ameritech, which together hold a 67 percent stake.
The sale would reduce their stakes but would not raise new capital for Matav, Laszlo said.
"They want to see what the market says about the price," Laszlo said. "They want to show that their investment was reasonable."
Deutsche Telekom and Ameritech together bought 30 percent of Matav in 1993 for $850 million and purchased another 37 percent of the company in late 1995 for $852 million.

The Hungarian government holds a 25 percent stake with the remainder held by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Finance Corporation, local governments and individual investors, Laszlo said.

Laszlo said four investment banks have been chosen to formulate plans for the sale, with a deadline of November 15 to submit proposals. They are CS First Boston, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.
